pageContext.desc: To Chicago lawyer and Congressman John V. LeMoyne, from his Pennsylvania-based family, including his abolitionist father.

pages.transcription:
John V. LeMoyne Esq.
Chicago
Ill.
[[Written on left side--
Ma - 1854]]

Dearest Johnny, I have waited day after day, with anxiety, 
for a letter from you, but in vain. I heard that Julia & 
her mother had gone unexpectedly and that you were not well 
that was sufficient foundation for uneasiness and would have 
made me very unhappy had I not also heard of the peculiar 
but not dangerous character of your infliction, moreover I 
have been in daily expectation of a letter. You must give 
me credit for patience, but understand at the same time 
that like many other things patience has a limit, so my 
dear fellow immediately on the receipt of this favor me with 
a long and interesting account of all your Job-like experience 
I hope you will take warning by this sad experience and 
take better care of your health in future, for I verily believe 
this impure state of the system has been induced by too 
much close confinement and entirely too little exercise 
mind that Johnny and take more exercise in the open 
air, you have always been used to it and you cannot 
do without it. I think if you could have remained here 
a little longer and taken more exercise, and regulated 
your diet or taken a little medicine, you might have 
got well sooner. I hope soon to hear that you are entirely 
recovered. I want to hear from sweet little Frank 
I do so want to see him, we were very much in hopes 
we could see him and Julia again. I became very 
anxious about the dear little fellow, and wrote to Romaine 
to let me know. Poor Julia she has a time of it with 
him and now you.

Charlotte has not yet returned. They still write that Willie is 
improving, and is bright & happy, he is a sweet interesting 
child, but I do not think he has as affectionate a disposition 
as Frank, cultivate it and deal very gently with him 
bear with him and soothe him, let his feel that you love 
him dearly, and when he is old enough to understand you 
he will obey you from a sense of duty and affection.
This thing of suffering children by the rod is cruel and 
nine times out of ten does more harm than good, by exciting 
their passions and arousing a spirit of antagonism.
let your child always breathe an atmosphere of love and gentleness 
and if it does not oust old Adam the rod never will.
Old Adam is pretty strong the spirit of love is almighty.
Various experiences and observations lead us in to various 
reflections. I suppose you are beginning to think I am 
indulging mine at your expense and troubling you with 
some of my theories, but never mind by the time you are as 
old as I am, perhaps you will have a few too. I hope this 
theory of love will be one?
We are all about as usual, Pa coughs a good deal but is as well as 
when you saw him.
I believe Julius has about made his mind to be a druggist but 
think he cannot study at home, poor boy I wish he could go to 
school as he wishes. Frank is doing very well.
We have had such a drought every thing is nearly killed.
no potatoes, no corn, no apples nor peaches, few grapes, we 
anticipate a hard winter. Wheat crop very poor, flour 8 & 9  
dollars. Our wine apples have all dropped off. 
I hope your provisions are not so scarce. Ice has to be brought

from Pittsburg, ergo, ice cream 10cts! I think the ice cream saloons 
have done a good business this summer. 
Romaine writes often and appears perfectly happy, talks 
of going to housekeeping in the spring, there is no mistake 
about Nicolas he is a good fellow. I expect Romaine 
over at commencement. 
Did we tell you Fanny Clendenin? was dead. She left 
4 children, died of typhoid fever. Tom & Mag Stockton 
are to be married very, he has rented and is fixing up the 
house next to Watson's, that was Mrs. Henderson's.
Do write to me dear Johnny or ask Julia to do so if you 
cannot. I want to come and see you this fall if possible 
but I cannot promise, if you want any flower seeds 
say so. The dry weather did not kill them. We 
watered a great deal, and have some beautiful verbenas
Kiss my darling little Frank and his dear Mama and tell 
them I love them and should be most happy to serve them 
and you know as much for yourself. I need not 
renew the assurances of my devoted affection to 
my beloved Johnny ~ M L M.

John V. LeMoyne, Esq. 
Chicago. 
Illinois.
[[Written up left side--
Recd March 27. th. 1854
Ma - Jane - Sis]]

John, if you don't write to me 
pretty soon, I'll conclude you are going 
to drop the correspondence. When am I to 
have the answer to the long letter I wrote 
the first of January? But I have a 
suggestion of my own to make, relative to
Master Classis' cognone?, I have been 
thinking that inasmuch as you cannot 
call him for Ma, your best substitute 
would be to call him for Uncle Val. 
Ma was regretting a short time ago 
that Pa had never permitted her to call 
one of her own boys for him. And yours 
would be next to her own. I think it 
would be very nice to have a little Valcoulon 
as if that don't suit call him Charlie.
Give my love to Julie and LeMoyne
jun. I will write to them before long.
I wish the Summer was her, I'm longing 
to see you all, and you more than all.
Oh it seems such an age since you 
were here, and so much has happened 
since. We feel a little uneasy 
about Ma, her health has been far 
from good this spring. She has so 
much pain in her breast.

A few days more will bring around the 
anniversary of your wedding, and we at home 
don't know anything about you as a married 
man. Julie gives most favorable reports, 
and I am beginning to think Washington 
is a famous place for "raising" husbands. 
John Wishart? and Alex Bond? are such 
models according to their wives' account.
But I only intended writing a few lines,
just to remind you that I was in existence 
which fact you seem to have forgotten, 
so good-bye, my darling brother. Lovingly, Jane
[[Written sideways--
John.]]

Washington March 21st_1854 
My Dear brother 
I hope you are all getting pretty 
well again. I hope the baby will soon be named 
for I dont think Ceasar is a pretty name and that 
is what we have to call it until we know its right 
name. Julia need not be afraid that I will not 
love her baby and carry it about for I am sure 
I will. My vacation begins a week from next saturday, 
and I expect to have fine times working in the 
garden. I have for my garden, a part of the chickens 
yard, but is it so shaded that hardly anything will 
grow there. I long to see you all and I wish 
that next week instead of being April was going to 
be June so that I could see you. I would like if 
you have time to have you answer this letter. Give 
my love to Julia and tell her that the next 
one will be to her. your affectionate sister 
Maddy

Mr John LeMoyne esq
Washington
Pa
John! you provoking fellow! 
Why dont you write to me???
I have a notion to write you an
awful scolding

My dear Johnny March 10"
I should always begin by thanking you for your  
last letter as it gives me so much happiness to hear 
from you, especially to hear that you are happy and 
well. I have only one wish left for you and that is 
that is that you may so live as to die the death of the 
righteous and reap his reward. Be not carried away 
with a desire for wealth and worldly distinction 
it will lead you into much trouble and misery 
and perhaps leave you in poverty and wretchedness. 
Enjoy the comforts and blessings of life as they are sent, with 
thankfulness and charity, doing good as you have opportunity 
out time here is short dear Johnny may we all be prepared 
to enjoy an eternity of happiness together. 
I have somehow still entertained or rather clung to the 
hope that I might always enjoy the presence of my children 
I now begin to feel as if that hope were insensibly slipping 
from my grasp. You think of settling where you are 
Charlotte of going farther yet, and so one after another 
is leaving, but it is what I must expect. I still have a 
goodly portion for which I am very thankful. 
I have had much pain and sorrow of heart about Romaine 
but when her time of trial is over if she continues of the same 
mind, she shall have my consent + blessing, all the past 
as tho' it had never been, and her place in my affection 
unchanged, my opposition was greatly excited by the 
dear that she had been imposed upon, and was

taken by surprise, if at the end of a year, with every 
encouragement to withdraw, and time to consider it in all 
its phases, she still finds her feelings unchanged she 
alone is responsible. I feel that my means have 
been performed. I await in peace, if it happen 
I will do all in my power to make them happy. 
We have had a painful, trying fatigueing time with our 
dear baby. We hope he is better but he still coughs badly 
and stands still at 17 pounds. 
Pa is not so well, and coughs a good deal. I tried? to 
persuade him he ought to go to Chicago and see about 
your purchases. I think it might do him good 
Riall has bought the Officer house for 3,800, 
the liquor law is repealed so I suppose all the shops 
will do a good business, in the way of making drunkards and ruining 
boys. I suppose we may be said to be imposing as every thing is high 
tho' by no means equal to Chicago prices. All our improvements 
are pragsessing?. Mr. Chislet was over last week to see to the Cemetery 
and I suppose to the new school house, which is to be built on 
the lot where Mrs. Crawford lived, the foundation was built 
last fall, for this improvement we are indetted? to Alex Gow's 
influence, his school is in great repute, and he is in his glory 
Ms. Redd thinks him second only to Mr. Hard of Philad. high school. 
Frank + Sis both go too? one quite pleased. At his examination 
last week, Mr. Alrich? was invited to come & stamp? the geometry 
class, but that could not be done, they astonished every one by their 
promptness and correct answers, we are looking for word to the 
enjoyment of a contest, examination +c+c. If we do not do business 
with such a rush? as you, we do not altogether vegetate?.

I must correct myself we are vegetating rapidly, our grass is 
looking green + sweet and our early flowers are beginning to 
bloom. I know you would enjoy a room over the hills and I 
know it would do you so much good. Mrs.? Hanna gone + poorly last 
week to the school girls alone. Frankies & evins?, Prepepions? & wares our Seniors. 
abut? theological students of Conourstery?. As Pa could not fo and Julius 
was very, very anxious to do so I had to go to Chaperone him, for 
he had no initation?, he was quite delighted, and had the satisfaction 
of hearing afterwards that the young ladies thought him remarkably 
agreeable. Pa tells him he will assist him in anything he wishes to learn 
and after he has studied Pharmacy he can study medicine. Julius 
appears to like the idea. 
The present report is that the Chartiers Valley railroad will come 
into town by Burton's and down the street, pass Mrs Barlow's 
make a curve this our lot? and unite near Mr. Hughes' 
would'nt that be bad! 
Dear Julia I began this letter several days ago and intended 
answering your kind letter and my dear little grandson's 
letter too, but I have been sick of a cold, quite sick 
yesterday, but much better today. I think I shall be very proud 
of such a smart child. I never had one that could write 
so well at his age, not even his father. I wish you could 
see John's first letter to me, it is quite a literary curiosity
I am sorry you have to feed him, as it may make him troublesome?
I think if you would drink the milk it would be better 
for you than he?. I wish you were where I could run in 
and help you to nurse, if your baby is anything like ours 
you would like a little help, for he keeps us all busy. A poor 
little girl of 4 years was burned to death day before yesterday down our 
street

her mother is woman of bad character, very poor and had gone 
only a square to buy bread fifteen or twenty minutes and 
left this child and one younger sitting by the fire, when 
she returned the room was filled with smoke one child 
standing behind the door crying, the other as far from the 
fire as she could get literally roasted to a crisp. 
I am sorry you cannot find a name for your baby. 
You must just call it what you please since John 
refuses to help you, or draw cuts. I am sure I shall 
love it any how, how would you like Jules Murray 
for yourself? I am sure John likes that name. 
please yourself and I shall be pleased. 
I hope we shall see you all here this summer. 
Romaine is anxious to know the exact time of your visit, 
that she may decide upon her own movements. I have 
withdrawn all opposition, her Pa says he will not prevent 
but he cannot approve, perhaps we did wrong in opposing 
her choice, but I feel better satisfied that she sure? we 
have had time to think of it, they have both behaved very 
well indeed, and it has made a great change in my 
feelings towards him. I cannot but respect and I am sure 
I shall love a man who is so honorable, self denying, 
and considerate. I felt exceedingly provoked at being 
imposed on, but I now believe I was mistaken. 
dear Julia say nothing about it. Romaine would like to be 
here when you come, but she is at perfect liberty from the 
first of April, her birthday. We are about as usual, 
I think I have not seen Charlotte look so well for some years, 
forgive my apparent neglect I think of you all every day and 
love you too, but I have been too much worried to write often 
much love my dear children I am always very glad to hear from you. 
Sincerely yours M LeMoyne.

JUN
Mr. John Le.Moyne
Chicago
Illinois
[[Written up left side--
Ma
1854-5]]

Dear Johnny, I am only going to write a few lines to tell 
you how much we shall be disappointed if you do not come 
and to try to persuade you that it is your duty to come. 
In the first place, your wife, child and self all need a 
trip home for your health, in the second place it is not 
right to sacrifice everything to business, it is right to 
attend to the health and happiness of one's family, and to visit 
one's friends, perhaps too while you are here or in Pittsburg 
you may find something to do and so come back. O that 
would be delightful, better live on less and have some 
comfort as you go along. I told Pa what you said 
he said you somehow had an idea that he had a great 
deal of money, which was not so, as to his health he 
says it is no better, (but he was better last week). 
Julius has not been well for some time, complains 
+ always feeling tired + weak, tho' he is better now. 
Pa wants him to study medicine and he does not want to, the 
fact is he does not like study of any kind wants to go on the 
railroad &c&c. anything but study, and that is what he 
needs, he will not even read. I know you have influence 
with him, and I hoped that your visit would do him good 
Pa seemed quite pleased too, and when I told you might 
not come he said very quietly (as tho he could not help it) 
perhaps he had better not neglect his business, so we 
would all be disappointed if you should not come. 
As I do not know your business connections with McLee 
of course I cannot judge the merits of the ease, but should

think you might come for a month and still go back 
in time. I should think Julia might come without 
you, we should be so glad to have her and help her nurse 
and I think she could enjoy a visit here in the summer
she must come to take Romaine's place, we shall be lonesome?
dear Johnny we want to see you all very much, we want to see 
the dear boy too, but after all we do not want to ask too much 
but if the cholera should break out, leave by all means.
Anna's wedding is to come off next wednesday. Julius is quite 
pleased that he is to be invited. Nannie is to go to Pittsburg with 
them, and return the next day, if Julia were there she could 
come home with her. You need not be afraid of a fuss 
we are not to have any. Mr. Mrs Wade & Mr. Rudd are to 
come the evening before and I intend to have them spend 
the evening with us as pleasantly as we can make it, 
the next morning after breakfast, the ceremony some refreshments 
and they will be off. They have all manifested a kind and 
conciliating? spirit, and why should we rebuff them. Nicolas 
has behaved in a very honorable and christian manner
The vindicate themselves of the underhanded scheming that 
I imputed to them, so it is my duty to forget the past and 
improve the future, even if they had injured me I should 
forgive. Poor little Willie does notimprove? much 
he coughs less, but he is still weak and just now has bowel 
complaint. Charlotte seemed determined to travel this summer 
but I think she would never bring him back. 
Pa says it is doubtful whether he will recover if he does it will 
only be through very great care and constant watchfulness

Charlotte is better and looks better than she has been for a long 
time. 
Poor Romaine has been much tried tho I hope she has not as 
much cause as she thinks. Pa told if she did this she need 
not come back, and there should be no visiting back and 
forth!! was not that cruel. I tell her I shall go, it is 
so near and easy to go I can do it, if you lived so near 
I would go often to see you without asking as the children say 
poor child I am sorry, so I shall love all the Wades if they 
are kind to her and make her happy, she thinks they 
will, so I am satisfied. 
Will Hughes is improving, he was here the other day, 
great many enquire about you. 
I send you some mignonette seed, you know it grows at 
all seasons, if you want a pot of it sow the seed in the 
pot and you may have it all winter. 
Tell Julia I hope she will conclude to come, we will try to make 
her comfortable and happy and love her and baby very much 
very much love to you all, do try to come. 
Very affectionately yours M. LeM,
I wish you could come before 
Romaine goes, she would feel so 
much better about it. 
Siss send a great deal of love to all three.

Mr John LeMoyne
Chicago
Illinois
[[Up left side--
Ma 1854]]

Dearest Johnny  Aug 5. 
I was rejoiced to hear you were well, that is, that you 
had not the cholera, for you know the reports were so 
terrifying we had some cause for uneasiness, as to your 
boils? I expect they will do you good, your manner of life 
for the last few years has been so different from your former 
habit that your system had become surcharged and coming 
to your healthy native air brought on a healthy reaction 
so you may feel encouraged to come home often to prevent 
stagnation & disease, for my part I think it is a partial 
duty to visit out friends, we enjoyed your visit very much 
and all become very fond of dear little Frank and would like 
very much to see him again. 
Romaine stepped in quite unexpectedly on tuesday evening, 
and a very pleasant little visit of two days and returned 
yesterday in a hack with Charlotte, poor dear little Willie 
you will believe we miss him very much. I think he is a little 
better, but the least thing would upset him. 
Romaine seems very happy, Nicolas had a profitable trip over 
is now hard at work, he was very ill at Niagara of bilious 
colic. R. thought Chicago beautiful, Julia talked of coming 
with her. We would have been very glad to see her, even without 
the dear baby. 
Is it true that the cholera has broken out again in Chicago. 
We have had a few cases that were supposed cholera, and 
we still have some dysentery, but otherwise healthy. 
Will Hughes continues to improve slowly and talks of going to Cincinatti

on a visit. 
I have suffered greatly from heat the last summer and this, 
it seems to prostrate me entirely, and induces many very 
disagreeable symptoms, so that I have been thinking I would like 
to go to a cool place next summer. I think it must be the 
heat as a few cool days revive me so much. 
Nannie & Julius were at the Canansbuy? commencement and Julius 
enjoyed it very much, he appears more contented and happy 
lately. After you went away Pa scolded him one day, and Julius 
seemed very unhappy and discouraged & rebellious, it made me 
very miserable and sick, he says he does not want to study a 
profession. I asked him how he would like to be a farmer, 
he thought he would like that pretty well, if he has a taste for it 
I think that would do as well as anything, but I told him what 
I have told him fifty times, improve yourself in every thing 
even in music, read, write, all your leisure time, 
if he would do that he would be contented enough, but he 
no taste for devoting himself to study, therefore some active 
employment would suit him better, he has always had a great 
fancy for working on a farm and with horses &c&c, so it might 
be just what would suit him. 
We are all in out usual health, and love you very much, 
do not get sick, but if you do take timely care of yourself,
Dear Johnny very truly and affectionately 
Yours M. LeMoyne, 
Sunday morning, forgive me dear Johnny I intended sending this yesterday 
but forgot to send it.
Mr. Springer? is either dying or dead, he jumped from cart in 
full speed and fell on the back of his head, and has been

insensible ever since, this was on tuesday. 
We have delightful cool weather now. I hope our heat is over 
Mama has been rather unwell for some days, she says she is 
growing weaker every day. Pa is as usual. 
Bob Haslit? is very ill of typhoid fever in Wheeling, his Parents 
were sent for yesterday. It seems quite odd to have no baby 
in the house, we hardly know how to pass the time we have so 
much leisure! I intend to walk and visit every day. 
Don't work too hard, nor don't be too anxious to make money 
'tis a great source of misery, if you make little, spend little 
you will be just as happy. 
Fred Chislet's family were made very unhappy by his coldness 
and fault finding when he was there. It was always 'the Edwards' 
do so & so', was not that abominable. I guess they feel 
as if he were lost to them, in some sense it is worse than death 
I should be greatly distressed to have a child lose all affection 
for me. Charlotte & Romaine were to go + see Julia yesterday 
I hope they will have a nice time together.

Sept. 9.
Dearest Johnny. I have delayed answering your last this long 
because it was so painful to me to deny so reasonable a request 
and one that is would give me so much happiness to grant 
But also immoveable as the mountains is the tyrant power 
that holds me. Before yours to Jane arrived I had expressed 
a strong desire to make you a visit, of course as made I 
expected opposition and prepared for argument, but of no 
avail, so I concluded as Pa was quite sick (he has been 
worse lately) and I hoped your dear boy was better and all well 
with you. I would still wait a little longer, but when your 
letter come yesterday and all my persuasions and entreaties 
failed I was almost beside myself, and cannot now think 
of you without tears and grief, let us hope this will not always 
last, poor man suffering has nearly destroyed his better part 
we are all greatly distressed about you and not one but would 
joyfully go to you. Charlotte was for starting immediately, but 
I told her I did not think it would be safe for Willie. 
Some days Pa is quite ill, takes a heavy chill sometimes of 
3 hours then follows high fever bad night &c, perhaps a little better 
the next day then worse again, very irritable and fault finding 
very, very strict with the boys caneing or whipping occasionally 
all these things dear Johnny and many more that I need not 
mention incline me to stay at home, for tho' I may not prevent all 
yet I am needed and things go on better when I am here, 
but if you were in Pitts. I could go anyhow for a day or two 
without leave. Why not take dear Frank to Beloit. Rebecca 
keeps boarders, it is so near you Julia could go there for a few 
weeks

Rebecca & Liz would be kind and attentive to her. Poor Jane is 
greatly grieved that she cannot go, but what can we do 
John. Pa is too sick to be left and too unreasonable for any 
thing, poor Julius was so much hurt the other at a lecture 
he got that he said he would leave the next day if he got a chance
I could not let him, but suppose I had not been here. 
It is hard & painful to have such things to write but you 
must know that we do not stay away willingly, we are bound 
by a hard necessity and can only submit just now. 
Pa allowed us to invite Nicolas, so he came for Romaine and 
was treated very well, he is indeed a very good honorable 
christian man, and they one all very kind and pleasant to Romaine 
and to us as for as they have the opportunity. 
Charlotte & Willie are quite well he is trying to walk and 
has five teeth, tries to talk too and is very merry, and likely 
to be spoiled. 
Mrs. Keisler? & Will start for Illinois today and will go 
thro Chicago, we are going to send you a box of grapes by them 
Will thinks he will have no trouble in finding your office, if this should 
reach you before he sees you, you will have to -mt? him at some 
of the depots, he goes to Stone's by the Rock island rail road. 
We have heard that the cholera is raging in Chicago, is it so? 
Fruit is still scarce & high, if you are afraid to eat the grapes 
preserve them. I hope they wont give you the cholera, let us 
hear from you often if only a few times, you have out 
warmest sympathies + best wishes, and my constant earnest prayers 
May the choicest blessings of heaven ever attend my beloved boy. 
I have directed Julius to put up the wine for dear little Frank 
Much love to dear Julia and tell her how very willingly

we would share & lighten her trouble + cares, how anxious we 
are to comfort her by out presence, and how gladly we would 
receive her & her little one and nurse and restore both if we 
could. O, if we were only nearer together!,
All send much love to you,
As ever truly yours M.L.M.

John V. LeMoyne Esq.
Chicago
Ill.
[[Written up left side--
Nov, 1854
Ma + Frank + Jane]]

Julie dear, I have nothing particular to 
say, not an item of news for you, but it's a 
long time since I have written you even a 
little note, and I'm afraid you'll forget 

me, if I don't remind you of my well being 

occasionally. How are you all getting along 
this cold weather. we can hardly keep 
ourselves warm. I presume little Frank

is quite well by this time. Willie? continues 
very well, and is as full of mischief as he can 
be. He is beginning to walk and talk 
and I think children are more interesting thei 
than at any other time. I have not time 
to write more. Good by. With ever so 
much love to both,
Janey.

Washington Nov 14th 1854
Dear John
I do not intend to trouble you 
with a very long letter but only to write you a few 
lines
We were alarmed by the cry of fire on Friday 
evening + Mr Bairds stable was burnt. It is feared 
that the fires of last fall are going to be repeated but as 
there has been none since I suppose it was accidental 
though no person had been in the stable since the 
day before
Charlotte is going to Pittsburgh to get 
one of her teeth fixed and Ma talks of going with her 
but I suppose she will not go 
Hunting it pretty 
good this year but Pa keeps Julius in the office 
very closely and he has not much time to enjoy it 
and of course he would not think of letting me go 
Mark + Bill Kisler and Sam Hart went out last 
Saturday and shot thirty squirrels
The fellows that went deer

hunting last fall are going again and Dick Fitzwilliams 
is going with them I do not know whether Brady is going 
with them or not but I suppose not. 
I had 8 or 9 dollars taken out of my 
box not long ago but I cannot find out the thief 
but I sold my pigs for which I received 10 dollars 
and I now have 30 dollars which I would like to 
have you take and put it out at interest for 
me as interest is so much higher there than it is 
here. If you would as leave? do this as not let me 
know when you next write
We heard from Pittsburgh that 
Franky was well but this did not satisfy Ma and she 
is very anxious to hear from you she says she intends 
to write to you soon
Give my love to Julia and 
the baby and all the rest of your family
Yours truly
Frank

Dearest Johnny, I have been intending to write you for 
a week past to ask about dear little Frank, we hear 
occasionally thro our Pittsburg friends, and have been 
rejoiced to hear the dear boy was better, but that is not 
like getting particulars from yourselves, has he entirely 
recovered and is he getting fat. Do leave off the win? 
and watch him as he grows up if the foundation 
of disease may be laid in infancy as Physicians say 
why may not tastes? be formed too. Better to die in 
infancy than grow up with a taste for liquor. I believe 
poor Frank Barlow received his before his birth. 
Charlotte received a letter from Mr. Wills yesterday, and 
in it one from William to him, from Sandwich Islands 
William was well and so far pleased with the warm climate 
John is still doing well in San Francisco, does not 
like the summer it is too cold, windy and wet, he sends 
Charlotte papers + letters regularly. Milton Latham? has 
been very kind to him, he was about returning 
in the yankee? Blade, but concluded to come by the 
Nicaragua line because it was the quickest, so 
he escaped the shipwreck, he told Mr Wills he was coming 
here this winter and Mr. Wills hopes here will treat him well 
for what he has done to him. Mr. Keisler + Will returned a 
week ago. I believe they were well pleased, but I do not hear 
any thing about moving.

we are getting along after the olf fashion, it you know what 
that is. Julius thinks he must have a situation by spicy?, 
he does not like studying medicine. Frank is doing 
very well at Mr Gors? I visited the school the other day 
and was quite delighted. Mr. Gors has done a great service 
to the cause of public schools by introducing the new 
system, which is indeed an admirable one. 
Our college + Seminary are doing a very moderate business 
our railroad nearly stopped, times are getting hard 
how are you getting along in your speculations, be cautious, 
My house is empty and taxes are high, and no sales to be 
made. Pa thinks I had better sell a lot to pay the taxes 
as I have no other way of doing. Charlotte was anxious 
to go to Pittsburg this week on dentist business and wished 
me to go with her. R. is anxious to have me and I have 
been politely invited, but the weather is too bad now + 
sprinkling snow, but perhaps I may go for two or three 
days. Anna Quail? McKennon is at home now, poor love? 
is getting very feeble, they think he will not live long.

Dearest Johnny July 23nd
I received your good kind letter, day before yesterday 
and I felt as if I could hardly go to sleep without thanking you 
for the kind and sympathetic feelings it expressed, feelings that 
have of late been withheld from me, and I have sadly felt alone 
yes dear John alone, you know how Pa would feel, that is was 
irony and must be stopped and so end, besides he is so sick I would 
not trouble him. Charlotte and Mr Wills worked the other way. R. 
ck first told me she would do whatever I wished as that was a thing 
more between them than that they had both confessed their 
affection for each other, so I wished that there might be nothing 
for a while till I become convinced of hers for him &c. 
but afterwards Charlotte had told her she was committed and 
could not retract of course he was disposed to hold on and 
R. sided with the strongest current, had R. been uninfluenced 
it would not have been. I told her that if it had been a pure 
spontaneous, uninfluenced attachment I should have looked 
upon it very differently, as it was I looked upon R as a 
charmed bird about to drop into the net so long and 
industriously woven for her it seemed as if my eyes were suddenly 
opened. I was frightened and grieved, you know I cannot 
control my maternal feelings. I was indeed distressed 
and I could not bear the sight of him, so I kept much out 
of the way. I suppose R. was governed, somewhat by her feelings 
(tho' you know they are not very deep) but it was her own 
proposition to wait a year without, corresponding, or to 
wait as long as I pleased. I suppose that would have been 
with correspondence.

the strongest feelings that R ever exhibits are resentment and 
stubborness. I was excited and as usual may have said many 
things I ought not, but I told her so afterwards and that I would try 
not to hurt her feelings any more, but we would wait on each 
other and live in love and be as happy as we could. Mrs Wade 
wrote her a short but artful letter, telling her? she unclear her 
as a dear daughter, and that in this state when two expressed 
their wish to be united before witness it was loyal, &c
I think she is a manoevring woman, and all there things 
make is so much worse. I cannot bear the thought that she 
should be taken by stratagem + storm. R. treats me with 
great coldness, and is very curt in her language, if this continues 
I shall think the year very long, dear Johnny I have to stop 
every minute to wipe my eyes. I cannot help weeping as 
I write, how deeply I feel the misfortune of such weakness 
I know it is not right it is injuring my health, but alas 
what can I do. I will fight against it, hard, I will think how 
blessings I have, what a dear good Johnny and three little ones 
to care for. As to Jane she is a good child but it is all papine? 
she reads and writes letters and disturbs no body but she 
does not disturb herself either about other people, it they 
are happy she lets them alone if they are unhappy she 
does the same, she was pleased with Mr W. thought I was very 
unreasonable, and asked me if she might correspond with him.
I told her I would rather not have anything to do with any of them
I felt so wronged and aggrieved. I wish you would give 
Jane and Charlotte after a while) a hint about their part in this 
matter. one thing more on this painful subject, you thought I knew 
Mr. Wade and knew they wanted R &c. I had seen him and never could

bear him, but was always told he was very smart as very good &c&
and sometimes it was hinted he wanted R. but I considered it like all

April 4"
Dear Johnny, do you know this is dear 
Franky's birth day. I wonder if he is thinking

thinking of him, my dear beloved child 
how I wish he were at home, and yet 
if he be safe & well, he will always be

terrible as it is, it is tho penalty we 
pay for our subserviency to the slave power

cruelties and desolations is necessary to 
open the wilfully blinded eyes of the 
North to the monstrous inequity,
had our obsequious dull effete? 
government proclaimed emancipation

and seemed rather to lament that

know I am not a fighting character, but

June 18"
My own dear Johnny,
I ought to have written you last, but indeed 
I had not the courage to tell you how 
sad I was. I am a little more calm just 
now, and do try to possess my soul in 
patience, not, to submit to what I caused? or 
great injustice and cruelty, but to possess 
the right spirit in resisting evil, and 
do nothing rashly or unadvisedly. I can 
not but feel that right will triumph, and 
I desire to do nothing of which I will repent 
above all things I must be hopeful, and 
I pray continually for a right spirit. 
I am now at Julius', and have been for two days, there is a difference you know 
between going 5 miles or 500 to see one's 
children. Julius is getting along very 
comfortably. I believe you have been here 
you know the place, considering it is so 
far from town, it certainly is a beautiful 
place, high & healthiful and wide, no 
sense of confinement, or narrowness, 
flocks of sheep cover the hill sides, 
horses and cattle and pigs in abundance

fields of ripening grain and trees 
loaded with fruit promise comfort 
and abundance. Annie seems quite 
contented in the Country, and often has 
her friends with, her Sister Mrs. Duvall 
paid her a visit last. She is a very pleasent 
social, intelligent, kind hearted, generous 
sort of a person, full of life and energy, 
her husband has been in the Army for a year 
and has just, since she was here, returned 
wounded, he is represented as very brave 
and daring, and has been promoted from 
Major to Col. in the first Virginia, was 
wounded in the battle of Port Republic, his 
little son 9 years, is now here and has been 
entertaining me this afternoon with some 
of his Father's hair breadth escapes, he is 
a fine, interesting child. Annie has had 
a step-Mother for a number of years, 
pretty much of a Vixen, it seem, Mrs. 
Duvall, having been away longer than Annie 
feels more at liberty to be communicative 
she is much like Mrs. Reed, tho Annie 
had told me about her, but she is very 
prudent. They seem to live on a large

scale having everything in abundance 
and Annie may not at first 
realise the necessity of economy, but 
I think she wants to do just right and 
will soon learn, she is sensible and 
firm, & seems to like us all. We were 
all out during Mrs. Duvall's visit and she 
was in twice to tea with us. Julius and 
Annie went home with her in a spring?
waggon and brought back, lots of things. 
I tell you there things merely that you may 
have some idea of Julius' people. Mr. Ruhn? 
went into Washington &c. with Gov. Pierpont, 
and will bring home his two daughters from 
school. Phila. We received a letter from 
dear Franky yesterday, like all his letters 
a week old. I hope he is well, but he says 
nothing about his health, he has been three 
times over the the battle field, and saw the 
terrible carnage, they were drawn up in 
battle away but did not come into conflict 
but he has been extremely busy, and nearly 
worn out, thinks our loss about 5,000, 
and is enthusiastic on McClellan

says he has seen & performed operations 
that he otherwise never would have 
witnessed, but wishes to go to Phila this 
winter. I want him to get discharged 
one month before his time expires 
or he will have no time to prepare for 
winter, as he has been faithful & loyal 
I think the government might oblige 
him that much, if I knew who to 
apply to I would do it, with his consent 
poor Janey is so unwell. I am quite 
worried about her. Charley? looks very 
badly with his whooping cough, and 
raises blood often tho in very small 
quantities, Sophie does not mind it, 
and Franny has not got it. Willie is 
deeply interested in his school. Mr. Wills 
is getting some business. Sarah thinks of 
spending the summer at Crepon? and 
renting her house to the Sisters of Charity 
not renting, but giving, for a year. 
None of the wounded or killed were known to you 
but Jus. Acheson & Purviance editro of Rep. 
John in the hand, P. in the leg?, poor Frank his 
last letter was to Nicolas to pay him, money he 
had borrowed, Nicolas has been very very 
kind to him, indeed he is a good fellow. 
Much love to you all dear dear Johnny
God bless you + yours is the daily prayer of 
your Mother.

flannel. I do believe in flannel, next 
the skin. I dont know that one is any 
warmer if the quantity of clothing be less,

good Johnny and no two ways about it

McClellan, and thinks they only want

amore? men to take Richmond, no

Constitution and Union are shadows 
let us fight for humanity & freedom

August 15.
Dear Johnny
I have been sick again and am still
an invalid, a mere trifle lays one up, to
be sure I had been eating corn, tomatoes &c 
but I do that all the time. O well it is not 
worth while to talk about it only it makes 
me dreadfully lazy, two letters from Franky 
today, one of Saturday and a note of Monday 
saying they had orders? to march at 2 o'clock 
nobody knew where or wherefor, but there 
was a rumor of crossing the Peninsula. I 
see that a large part of the army left the 
same day in transports and I hope Frank 
was in one but he will be cared for, he says 
a cadet can, when his time is up, get a 
contract and hospital boot, it is were not for 
graduating he thinks he might try that too, he has 
applied to be put in a general Hospital, if he 
succeed he may go to Phila, he thinks he will be 
at home about a week, says they enjoy bathing in 
a mill pond very much and he has suffered 
but for a few days from heat, owing to their 
supply of ice failing.

You are mistaken for once dear Johnny 
I never read the Tribune. I dare say I 
should endorse its principles, but it is too 
dry and elaborate for my cursory reading 
in politics. I get my emancipation 
politics from the Bible, for I never read 
Pa's abolition papers either, as I dont 
appreciate the fruit they bear, but 
we wont quarrel when the war is over 
because black men have helped us, as 
help they must, not because we have not 
men enough, but because their deliverance 
is decreed and that is the way we will be 
made to acknowledge their humanity, 
if this so not come true, I will yield 
the cloak of prophecy to a truer prophet.
Enlisting is progressing?, Davey's? company 
is growing and is now encamped in the 
fair Grounds, several other companies 
are forming, eight students went from one 
class to the Anderson Troupe. Many 
other students are gone, out College is 
almost gone, it is thought they will close

Poor Tom Elliot, isn't it sad that he is 
deranged. I suppose it has been brought on 
by intemperance. David is wild too. 
I have not heard from Jonathan lately presume 
he must be better. Focee?, who is a presbyterian 
preacher, and Will Stockdon, of Crosscreek 
who is also a licentiate?, and another 
presbyterian preacher from Nicorg?, are 
raising a company. Fred & Will to be 
Lieutenants. Tom McKinnan is to 
join Will Templeton's company, you 
remember Will, he has been doing well 
and has joined the church since he went 
to Port Royal, they are now at Fredericks, 
bugo? Dr. McKinnan is getting a little better 
they have had the regualr camp fever. 
Rob. Reed & Dav. Watson are enlisted in Dav. Acheson? 
company, this evening I hear it is full and 
will probably leave on tuesday. 
harvest is just over and Julius pretty tired 
he had no notion at all of going to the War 
I wonder if it is as cold in Chicago as it is 
here. I think I will make a fire, being sick 
always makes me chilly.

War times don't seem to interfere much 
with M. Harding's business he is going to 
Phila. Tomorrow for goods, and Nanny will 
spend part of the week at Julius'. 
Annie reminds me of Julia in many 
things, the same high minded generous 
disposition, unselfish and kind and 
affectionate. Mary Cope? has lived out her 
time, you know she cannot live long with 
any body. Annie says if the girls will 
only go out and teach her to take bread 
she is not a bit afraid but she can get 
along, and they have promised. Sis is now 
saving her time in the kitchen (with a good 
girl) Taking week about with Jane, 
indeed we have so little exercise, I feel 
like sending off my girl today. I suppose 
I should soon call her back, as I am not 
worth a straw. Much love to you all 
My darling children. I am still able to love 
you and claim to be accepted as 
your loving sincere Mother.

Dear Johnny, I dont believe I ought to 
write to you today, but it is the last day of the 
week and you will be disappointed, but 
some days I cannot write, but I can let you 
know we are all well, physically at least,

fitted for the Master's use, for Trule, 'if in 
this life only we have hope, we are the 
most wretched of beings, let us then forgetting 
the things that are behind reach forward 
to those that are before, does it not 
overwhelm one with solemnity to think 
of the thousands of souls that this war 
has ushered into eternity, without any 
preparation, the thought of stepping 
as it were, from scenes of stripe + blood 
into the Divine presence is very awful. 
But even in judgement is mercy shown.

and we know that the judge of all the 
earth will do right. Our Town has 
been quite excited of late, with the forming?
of companies. 3 are now encamped in 
the Fair Grounds. Dave's company 
was more than full, two bodies of 
the Ringgold? Co. were taken there a few 
days ago, home to be buried, they 
had been shot by Guerrillas in W. 
Virginia, it roused the people's feelings 
& sympathies, and they feel more + more

I have not heard from Frank since they 
left Hamson's? landing, he wrote wednesday 
that they had marching orders. I suppose 
he went with the sick down the river 
Dr McKennon is a little better, was down stairs 
today. Jill was in town today with her baby a 
fine big boy, she looks as well as ever, and

consumption, Mary Boone was when she

McKennon thought she could go no farther 
well she went to where Mr. Spear lives, and

Brady Koontz? is riding about again as

Much love to you all dear Johnny God

perhaps I may add a little tomorrow

Wednesday 27"
Dear Johnny
We are in the midst of our festivities. Julius 
arrived on friday, after having been expected for stince? a 
four days, and having been left by the stagoonoessy?. So 
they were the bien-venue, they bring good account 
of dear Franky. Julius says he looks as tho he had 
been melted and run in his clothes he is so fat and 
large weighing 180, and is in good health. I think 
he has too much health, for Annie says he has pimples 
on his face, his duties are altogether professional 
those of assistant surgeon, his pay barely keeps him 
has rations, pretty plain and no variety unless he 
buys something, has to clothe himself, but is well 
pleased and thinks he will go into the ryalar? 
service, for 3 years as surgeon, when he has graduated , 
but I don't, he was very much delighted to see Julius 
and was with him a good deal. Says he was quite 
pleased with his new Sister. She has a quiet way 
of accommodating herself to circumstances, and 
seeming contented and at ease, observant, and 
I should think judicious. Simple and plain in manner

dresses neatly, but never speaks of it, looks as if her 
health were not very good, rather delicate in 
person - black hair, blue eyes, complexion not good 
heavy brown, indicative of tempter of firmness, 
we will presume the latter, as she is said to be 
amiable, so if she have health, she may do very 
well, her step Mother is Mrs. Wade's cousin 
the last of the race of John of Gaunt?, who was 
the son of Ed. 3", they are from Maryland. 
All the children call ehr Mrs. Kuhn, Annie did 
not tell me this, she is not at all communicative 
Well we had a very nice pleasant reception 
house full. I turned it over to Jane. Pa was in 
a while, chatting with the old gentlemen, and has 
been very pleasant all the time, tho he has been 
very unwell for a week, not sleeping, or rather 
not going to bed, (for I think he must sleep some) 
for four successive nights. Julius goes out 
and in, and I guess feels now that Pa will do 
well by him. Mr. Harding has just returned

from Phila & N. York, business is rather dull 
but he is making a living. Pa seems to think he 
is getting a little behind hand, but I dont know 
Nanny says he will try to buy the house they 
are in if it is offered for sale, it would have 
many bidders. Charlotte & Romaine would both 
like Julius', and are very unwilling he should 
sell, so I suppose he won't. Mr Wills has not 
some yet he has been thinking of the army. 
Mr. Stanton offers him a place on Grant's staff, 
he wanted one on Fremont's but it was full and 
more , he has been talking of it along time, and 
has studied military tactics, a good deal. i 
think he is much disappointed about his suit 
and poor Charlotte feels very badly. I pray 
it may do them good, reverses and trials are 
often our greatest friends, we are rough diamonds 
and need much clipping and polishing. The 
world would be a poor portion for an immortal 
soul. What infinite love & condescension, then, in our 
Creator to prepare us for a higher destiny.

We came near having a serious accident yesterday. 
Nanny was going from here and when she got to the 
Willow trees, thought she perceived something wrong about 
her cistern, which is a hogshead sunk in the ground with 
a small lid that shuts down with hinges, She hurried 
on and two little feet held by the lid and when 
she came near heard the hoarse voice of a child 
it was Susie, she held on to the edge and the lid held 
her feet, her head touches the water, in a few minutes 
more she must have given way, when she was carried 
in she told her Mother, she steamed and steamed, 
and Tould'nt see the 'lye. She was deadfuly 
fighteneed. Today she could not be coaxed into the 
yard. We dont know how long she was there, she had 
screamed herself hoarse. Julius did not see 
Miss Beach. I think cutting children's hair very 
short might give them the earache. Keep it long 
untill warm weather. Sophie has it sometimes, her 
hair has not been cut, but she has very little, she is at 
times hard of hearing, we think it is from her tonsils. 
P.S. I was going to close without telling you who 
I am, for I had taken another leaf to tell you

August 27'
Dear Johnny
I received your letter today, but none 
from Frank, none since the removal 
from Harrisons landing, So I am getting a 
little fidgetty. I expect he has written but 
the overwise policy of detaining the mails 
interferes very unpleasantly with how the 
correspondence, a letter from Mr. Wills to 
day says Heintzleman was in Alexandria 
and he presumes Frank is with him but 
I rather think he would be sent on with 
the sick, hope I may hear soon, he is very 
good about writing. I have quite a large 
bundle of letters. What do you think, the other 
day I took it into my head that it was 
always safe to keep old letter, in case 
of death of accident, they might fall into
strange hands, so I would burn a parcel 
so I gathered up two parcels, and hurried 
down to the kitchen fire and threw in one 
reserving the other for another time, but in 
the meantime, I repented and cannot 
make up my mind to burn the rest. 
So they are put away. I save all of Frank's 
because they are a kind of history of this part of 
his life, and might be read by any body.
I am glad you have so recruited, it was 
always Father's remedy when he did not feel well

to go to the woods a week or two, you see we 
are a wandering tribe, and cannot help loving 
its room at large. i think would have been 
like me if she had had the chance, but she is a 
great deal better, a lady called to see me the 
other day, who had known me in Chillicothe?, and 
used to visit Uncle Belt's? because she was an 
episcopalian. Miss Doddridge, her father was 
the first episcopalian minister in this western 
region, has written a book, Notes on Virginia'. 
and she is trying to issue an edition with his life 
written by herself, it seemed like old times to 
hear of my old friends and acquaintances, 
our military operations are still lively. The 
town is crowded all the time, and people go 
continually to see the men drill. I have heard 
but of one drunken soldier, democrats hold 
back of course. John Fitz and his boys are violent
secech. Frank + Will say if they are drafted they 
will go to the other side & fight. they wont fight 
for niggers, poor ignorant sinners, they may be 
glad to get niggers to fight for them yet, 
I dont believe LeMoynes so bad, but Will is 
the meanest, for some time ago he became 
alarmed lest he should be mobbed and he 
joined a company, The hypocrite, and so well 
did he play his game he was made a low grade 
officer. I do wish such men could all be 
drafted, we have many, and all the republicans

are going to war and there traitorous asses will 
control the elections. I do think the elections 
ought to be put off or let the women vote. 
Was not there a capital letter of our friend Horace 
to the President. I had been thinking of just such
a thing, but poor Lincoln isnt he a granny
of a man, that letter and his reply to the colored 
men are wonderful efforts, how does he survive 
do you think. I expect Seward & Blair must 
support him. I think if my old french teacher were 
here, he would slap his old bald head, as was 
his wont when excited and cry out, 'Shame for
me country', however I am not without hope 
for Mr. Lincoln says he will do all to save the 
Union - so let us be patient. We know that Our 
Father's at the helm, and let us do all we can 
well we make shirts, pickles, and cakes for 
our soldiers, we wave our little flag and smile 
out approbation and encouragement, and if all 
our men go to the war we will take their places 
as for as in us lies. We are as usual. I think you
are mistaken about my status. I am troubled with 
torpidity? of the liver and digestive organs, light 
fruits and some acids suit me better than
solid food. I am fond of meat, but it does 
not seem to suit me. As a general thing I 
have been pretty well this summer, my mind 
has troubled me more than my body. I am 
very nervous, and the war for freedom has

very deeply absorbed my feelings, and 
strengthened my principles, of independence. 
Mrs. Sarah Wilson dies today, she has been a 
sufferer for many years, and had no prospect
of relief, her disease was tumor of the womb
and she has suffered intensely, yesterday she 
refused her medicine saying it would only 
prolong the struggle, she has been dying two or 
three days, it a comfort to her friends that 
she was fully prepared and in a happy frame 
of mind, she was a lovely active christian, 
poor Mrs Baird, she has lost so many friends 
and children, and she is (not today) but generally, 
so bright, cheerful and affectionate and gentle, 
they now have five grandchildren, whose 
Mother is dead, and they are bringing them up 
in the right way too. Sue, Jennie and Ellen
just devote themselves to their Mother and those 
children, and Todd supports them by his grocery
I suppose the father who lives in Missorri must 
help them some, that is living to some purpose, 
the richest people don't do the most good, do they, 
it is better to be good than rich, so let us pray to 
be good and as good and always love one annother 
Much love to you all my darling children.
May you be happy and deserve to be so prays 
your faithfully loving
Mother.

John LeMoyne

Sept 3d
Dear Johnny, I am reduced 
to this fancy sheet , to night, but 
I do feel so sad and 
anxious I can do nothing
so I will write a little to you, and try to 
write so you can read. I am sorry my 
last was so unintelligible, not that it was 
any great loss, but it is really provoking to 
get such a letter. I hate it, sometimes I 
am so uneasy and nervous. I think faster 
than I can write, and find myself writing 
the first & last letters of a whole sentence 
other times my materials are bad. We 
live fast these times, don't we, so much 
excitement, and sadness, and so many 
changes, and just now our affairs are 
assuming such a fearful aspect. I can 
not but feel that we are suffering the 
judgements of God, for our great national
Sin, of refusing to recognise the humanity 
of one of the families of the earth. 
We have as a nation degraded them to the 
level of brutes.

Frank's last letter was from Alexandria 
he spoke of the battles that have so alarmed 
the country, as skirmishes. His division
had gone when he arrived at Alexan. 
he says, We. I suppose he means, one 
battery, as he speaks of the horses? & guns? 
and speaks of his division being at 
Waneuton, and I see Heintzleman is 
guarding Throughfare Gap. So 
Frank's battery was left, and they 
were awaiting orders, his general, 
Kearney, is reported dead. Tom 
McK. returned today, rejected on 
account of his youth, he visited the 
battlefield, and I presume that cured?
him, he saw the boys who buried 
Will. Templetom, he was shot in the 
bowels, at dusk and lingered till 2
in the morning, and was buried at 
Centreville, and the boys say the -groun-
ground is so tramped, he can never 
be found, his brother has gone on for 
him, his Mother is a very good woman

and takes comfort in the thought, that 
he died doing his duty, only 14 of 
his company were engaged. We 
have 5 companies in camp, but I 
heard this evening that the three 
infantry companies were ordered 
to Pittsburg,, did you know Colin 
Wilson of -W-. Alexander, father of Mary 
Lee, Jane's dear friend, he has been 
living in a corner of Missouri for a 
few years, in a cabin on the prairie 
raising cattle. Ten days ago, or so, 
he was visited by a large band of 
guerrillas, entirely robbed of every 
thing he possessed, and barely 
escaped with his life to Camp 
Scott, 25 miles, as he says nothing 
of his wife, who is a very brave woman 
we presume, she was unmolested, but 
imagine her condition, one of their 
neighbors, a good inoffensive man 
was shot by the rebels. Tom was not 
on the battle field but saw the wounded brought 
in to Alexandria, did not see Frank

Jane received a letter from Mrs. Bell with 
a photograph of the Dr. [She?]] said they had written 
to you & Julia and had not received any 
answers to their letters. thursday morning - 
Our town is alive with sadness, our boys are 
starting, and the town is collected at the Court 
House to harrow up the depths of their feelings 
and sadden the poor fellows. I don't like these 
formal and prolonged partings, they should 
send them forth with cheers of encouragement, 
and assurances of support, but such 
scenes may be good for the people they 
do need to be softened down sometimes. 
Wotring's sale comes off this week. Aunt Rose 
and Lizzie were here a few days ago. I told her 
I wanted some corn for you, she has not 
much but will probably let me have some if 
you want it, we have dried for ourselves. 
Kate Wotrins is to be married very soon to a Son 
of Dr. Howard's of Pitts. Much love to you 
dear Johnny, the increasingly bad 
news from all quarters saddens us 
May God have mercy and deliver us 
as he only can. Your loving Mother,
I meant Sis was a good girl

are you. Well it can't be helped so, do 
as I do, when I can't help it. Perhaps I ought 
have written last week, and how could I?

to shake off all disease, he seemed to

little more grave, when left to himself, 
but readily joins any proffered amusement.

have showed us his face instead 
of his back, and everbody asks if that 
lady is Julia. Romaine insisted that 
she saw dahlias & roses and the 
children under the trees, now if you 
have not got dahlias & roses, I suppose 
you have something else. I have not 
written to you since I received them 
they were thought very good pictures. 
I sent Julias corn, by Frank, he 
will ship it if he has time, if not

Nicolas will, so look out for it
it is in a box, sasaparilla bow, I think. 
Julius and Annie seem in better 
spirits, have been in oftener, and spent 
pleasant evenings with us at Charlottes 
where Romaine was. Mr. Wills went 
back to Washington two weeks ago, he 
had business, and seems to be doing 
pretty well. Lizzie Wade went at the 
same time, to N. York, for a short time 
Mrs. Wade is to visit Pittsburg this winter 
and come back in the spring to live 
that and keep house, the firm exing?
them, and they all expect to have at 
least comfortable dividends. 
Julius does not think your proposal 
would suit him, his accounts are 
prepared and will soon be presented 
he has some notion of buying up 
sheep and taking them to this? to sell 
Annies brother has made a great deal 
at it this summer, but I discourage 
that, Julius, was never made to be a

speculator and would not succeed 
the partnership with Mr Harding 
meets more favor from us all
they might board in their own house 
with Charlotte, the business just now 
is very good, tho I don't know how 
the confinement would suit Julius he 
likes open air exercise. Pa thinks of 
buying more land, believing it to be 
the best & safest investment, if he 
would only give Julius a farm, that 
would suit him best. Much love 
to you all my Darling boy, and 
to all the dear children, and 
never dare think you are slighted 
or forgotten by your loving 
and devoted Mother, 
P.S. they told me at the store, that 
that was Cochineal, in my own 
private opinion. I consider it doubtful, 
but of no importance whatever

Chicago

Sept 29'
Dear Johnny
I suppose you don't feel slighted as you
probably guessed the reason of your 
not getting a letter last week. Frank 
came on saturday, we had not heard
from him for some time so hardly 
knew what day to expect him, or 
rather them, for Romaine had written 
us, she would come with him and 
bring Lizzie Wade. Mr. Wills was away 
and expected too so we were all in 
a state of expectancy for some days 
and I concluded to wait until I could 
say Frank is here, he is well now 
tho just recovering from the jaundice 
he is enjoying the comforts of home 
with apparent relish, how we wish 
you could be here to help us with out 
grapes & peaches. Frank was fruit 
hungry, and seems to have a great 
capacity for grapes. Nicolas came 
but went home this morning.

Romaine has been very unwell and 
nervous since the explosion, so we are 
exerting ourselves to amuse her. I am 
going to have her give Sis singing lessons, 
last night they were singing sacred 
music, at Charlotte's, untill 10 o'clock 
Frank + Nicolas had a delightful visit 
to Julius' yesterday afternoon, and we 
are all to go some day in a waggon and 
have a good frolic, we always 
make up out minds to enjoy ourselves 
in the country, and Annie is always 
glad to have us come. I told Julius 
what you said, he is making out 
his accounts now and I don't know 
how it will all end. I do blame 
Julius some too, he is not a man of 
business, but people ought to have patience 
with their children, and help them 
along, so they may learn to take care of 
themselves, and if some need more 
teaching and patience than others, why 
let them have it, but live to do good 
not to amass money.

Our militia came home yesterday 
morning, dusty and tired, but well
Sam Haslett? brought two little contraband 
with him. 
I will try to get you a piece of cochineal 
flannel, but I really don't believe there 
is any thing in the color, it is not half as
permanent a color as madder, but every 
one wants his own experience so you 
can try. I have no doubt there is great 
virtue in flannel. I am much since? 
I wear it. I have worn it all summer 
and have not had a cold, but the 
season is coming on, so I must not boast, 
people tell me I am looking well. 
The fact is just now we are all well but - 
Romaine - and she is improving. 
We think of you and wish you 
were here. Jane says I do wish 
John was here no knowing whether 
we shall all ever meet again 
but I now indulge that feeling 
I am too hopeful for that

I always expect to meet again
love to you all dear Johnny
be assured you are well remembered 
by all and more especially 
by your own loving Mother.
We are very busy, it takes half 
the time to go round? and 
gather peaches and grapes
and the other half to eat them

John Le Moyne
Chicago
Illinois

Oct 24"
Dear Johnny, It seems but a few days 
since I wrote you, and yet the last week has 
been so full. I feel as tho it were a long time 
since Frank left us, two weddings, 3 or 4 
deaths among out acquaintances have made 
us live thro' a longer period of time than 
is measured by a week. Mrs. Young's trial 
in the death of her son is very great. They 
are southern people, her friends live in 
Virginia, they have been here only a few 
years, and cannot be expected to be very 
northern, and she was reluctant to let her 
son go, he was moreover rather wild,
during his lucid intervals he did pray 
and ask his father to pray for him, but 
that was only a death bed repentance. Yet I 
believe they have hopes in his salvation, but 
they are in great grief. Mary Watson's baby 
was brought here and buried on monday,
that was a sad stroke, very sudden and 
they are prostrated in sorrow, it is hard 
to lose a first & only child.

Frank reached Philadelphia thursday 
morning and has a pleasant boarding house
on Girard Street, between 11' & 12", his 
address is 'University of Pennsylvania'. 
boarding 6.50 a room to himself with heat
& light, he expects to study hard. I don't 
think he has altogether decided about 
going into the army, the war ought to be 
pretty well over by that time, if we 
want to do any thing, for the democrats 
may come into power, isn't it too bad
the way the elections are going, but I hope 
still, that it will be all for the best. The 
prospect of losing the opportunity of doing 
something ought and I hope will, arouse 
more active measures, if anything can 
arouse McClellan, & Lincoln, Lincoln 
it seems is rather surprised at the crossed out -- poor and
terror? his proclamation has produced in the 
south and the favour? it with which it is 
received in the North, and among Unionists
at the South.

I could have told him that long ago
but, you know, he would not listen to me
perhaps the time had not come untill
now, but his sentiment had to be modified.
I have just received your letter. I thought I 
had got one a day or two since, and intended 
answering it last night, but after writing 
to Frank and making a visit to Mrs. Hartford 
in her sadness, it was too late for the mail 
besides I could not find the letter, so this 
morning I took a good hunt, but in vain 
and now when my letter is half written here 
it comes. I must have dreamed it, for it is 
just as I thought it. You may imagine that 
I was looking over you shoulder. I did 
put in the seed corn, the chives, & tarragon 
&c. I hope you have it by this time. I think 
another year that we have grapes I will 
pack you a box. Frank took some and 
says they carried well, but he fears they 
will not keep but I suppose you don't 
want to keep them either. I sent a few 
dried cherries for the children, so I dried
myself.

I do not think merchandising will 
suit Julius at all and I told him so 
he thinks too that he would not like it at all 
and will only resort to it in the last pinch
he ought to stay on a farm, he is as thin 
as a rail, and says he is not half ass strong 
as he used to be, we will see by spring. 
As I made a mistake of a day I may as 
well let you have the benefit of it 
and send it tonight. So my darling 
good night and very much love 
to you & yours, but do take care 
and not let that colt break your neck
if I should not hear from you at 
the regular time I will conclude 
something had happened. Julius' 
colts are so gentle any body can ride 
them and so pretty & black. 
God bless & keep you dear Johnny
and make you a blessing to your family 
and the joy of your loving Mother

John LeMoyne
Chicago
Illinois

Oct 29"
Dear Johnny,
I am sorry you have not your box. I wrote to 
Romaine about it some days ago, she said she 
would enquire about, and I will write again
in these days of dishonesty and roguery it is 
necessary to see that one gets one's own
this war has wonderfully? developed the 
intense corruption of human nature is it 
not humiliating to think of what a stock 
we come. We have been very much 
provoked to hear how our delicacies and 
comforts for the sick soldiers have been 
appropriated to the use of the attendants 
and surgeons of hospitals, word has reached 
us too (we hope it may prove false) that the 
socks were knit ourselves have been sold 
by the quartermaster for money! only 
think og our working so hard to enrich 
such a moreol?, but alas so it is in this 
world, the innocent suffer for the guilty 
So you are rather diseneraged? about the war 
I am just beginning to hope, it the edict 
for emancipation had taken immediate

effect, we would probably be experiencing 
some of its benefits ere? now, so wait untill 
the first of January, and unless we have 
sinned beyond redemption, you may 
expect something. God could not help us 
when we were supporting slavery, so when 
we are prepared to give that up and fight 
for human rights, we shall have him on 
our side, that is the reason we have lost 
all we had gained. he was trying us, but we  
were weighted in the boland? and found 
wanting.
We are having delightful fall weather, we have 
a little show of snow, but it melted away 
in the morning sun, and it now looks like 
Indian summer, harvests all good and 
gathered in, fruits plenty, but apples 
not soon for keeping, we have none 
from the farm, and Julius but few 
I have enquired about vinegar. Dr Templeton 
will have some in a few months, but I 
think I might get a barrel of cider. 
John Baird thinks it could be sent

via Wheeling for 150.
Old Mrs. McGiffin died a few days ago 
she was keeping house for Tom whose 
wife died about a year ago, and a family 
of little ones. I expect I told you Mrs. James 
Quail was dead. I saw Belle not long ago 
looking as well as ever, she enquiried 
for you & yours, she has 4 boys. 
Sis went to Julius' on Tuesday and will 
probably remain the rest of the week. 
Julius has made up his mind to leave 
Mr. Varro?, Smith's son in law, is looking 
for a form and went today with Pa 
to see Julius', and likes it better than 
any he has seen, but thinks Mr Smith 
will not buy? so longed? one. but perhaps 
he may, Julius' present intention is to go into 
the store with Mr. Harding, whose business 
is very good indeed just now. I guess 
they will board with Charlotte the first year. 
I don't believe the stock turned out as  
well as they expected, the sheep are most 
profitable, of the cows, one died from

an injury, the others they do not milk 
their calves are nearly all males, pretty 
soon, but no profit, nobody buys them 
we have one of the cows, she is very fine 
plenty of good milk, the mare Kate 
is not very handsome, but a splendid 
animal, never needs a whip, lively 
but gentle, safe & swift. I just wish 
she was my own. I know I could drive 
her, and Sis is always delighted to get on 
her back. Frank was much pleased with 
the oldest colt? and wants him, so does Julius 
the other two are young yet, but guess they 
are good too, all of them black, one female 
haven't I given you an account of the horses 
now. I wish you were there to take them 
you had come to the sale as I suppose there 
will be one. Much love to you my 
dear boy and to your dead children 
you may rest assured of the abiding 
love of your affectionate 
Mother.

Nov 5"
Dear Johnny
I am afraid you think I am neglecting 
you and perhaps I ought to have written
you a line, but I don't could have written 
a decent letter, and I hardly know why 
either, fine weather that compelled me 
to go out much, goes & comers, indisposition 
to write &c, added to all which 
time would fly. O how swiftly, how 
first & foremost, about the vinegar,  I can 
get it and the bowel? is a good iron 
found, but I think the weather is too 
cold, it would freeze and thaw would 
spoil it, I think, but it can be kept 
untill warmer weather. Julius has 
just been, and he & Pa cannot agree 
about amy of the farms, for the small one 
near Cooks, he asks 2.00 doll rent, or 
5,000 sale, for the next 400 & taxes

which would be about 150 more. 
the houses are tolerably good but 
needing repairs, no fruit, and 
rather unpleasant in many respects, 
tomorrow he goes to Wellsburg to see 
Mr. Kuhn?, who tells him not to be 
discouraged, he will buy him a 
farm in 3 years, but he wanted to 
know what Pa would do first, and 
feels that he is badly treated?
Pa has told him that he will satisfy 
him when they settle, as yet he has 
found no farm to rent, but I think 
he will, Annie prefers the country 
now and wants to be near here, 
rather than go to Brooke County. 
Nicolas & Mimi unexpectedly made 
their appearance on thanksgiving day 
and remained several days. 
N. & Dick Lee went out to Julius

to hunt. They were not very
successful, but took home a few rabbits 
and squirrels, and had a nice time 
generally, for the last two days
Eliza Tinney? and Miss Sellers have 
been visiting Charlotte. Eliza's daughter
and Miss S' sister are at the
Seminary, you know we always feel 
bound to help each other entertain 
company, she enquired about you.
She is just the same worldly extravagant woman 
she made a foolish marriage and I think 
has repented of it all her life, talks 
principally of style, splendor, and magnificence, 
how tiresome, and trifling such people are  
I am always sorry when Charlotte has to come 
in contact with her. I don't think Charlotte 
has quite made up her mind to go to Washington 
the expense seems to make her hesitate.
I think Mr Wills is doing pretty well,

Frank has been offered a situation in a 
hospital in Phila. but he thinks he is 
busy enough, he would have to drop some 
of his present studies, he thinks some of 
going into the army for a year of two,
but I don't think it would be a good way 
he does not intend to be a mere surgeon
so unless he is needed, which I don't 
think is likely to be the case, he had 
better commence his life practice.
I don't want him to come here, unless he 
particularly desires it, for I would not,
and I think it would be for the better for Julius to go
away too. I hope and pray you may do right, 
from a sense of duty to God, forbearing 
recrimination and evil thought, let us 
suffer wrong, rather than do it, in all faith 
and patience, and quietness, and then 
and only then, will all work together for out 
good, let us not do evil in hopes that good 
may come, let us rather forget the evil 
and seek the good, dear Johnny, sin 
is the cause of misery, and nothing so 
much distresses me as the thought of sin or 
wrongdoing in my children.

how wretched was I last night and what 
bitter tears I shed, to see dear Julius 
so vexed and worried about his Father,
conduct to him. I know it is very hard 
for him, but since it is, and we can 
not help, let us try to bear our trials 
without sinning against the commands 
of God, be ye angry and sin not,
So it is better for him to go, but I do not 
want him to feel angry or wicked 
about it, let it be done, in peace and 
gentleness, inwardly I mean for nothing 
else has been done. Annie is a dear 
good girl, and is doing all she can
industrious and energetic and chiefly 
going all kinds of country work.
She feels in better spirits now that her 
papa has undertaken to do for them 
and I think they will get along.
Well, this is the old song over again

and you will think you have heard it 
often enough, morale, dear Johnny 
be very kind and good to your children 
and your wife, devote yourself to 
their best interests in a pleasant way,
that in your old age they may bless 
you and smooth your passage to 
the tomb. Not that I have any fault 
to find, for I know you love them all 
very sincerely, and may they always have 
reason to honor and love their father,
and Mother. I don't know that a 
dereliction of duty on one side abodes?
the other, certainly not. God bless 
you all, and fit you for all your duties 
so prays your loving and devoted
Mother.
